discussion.content: It encrypts and isolates in-use data and the applications processing that data, thereby preventing unauthorized access or modification is an accurate description of the key features and benefits of OCI Confidential Computing. Confidential Computing is a feature that leverages hardware-based Trusted Execution Environments (TEEs) to protect data and applications from unauthorized access or modification while they are in use by the CPU or memory. This adds an extra layer of security to cloud computing, as it protects data not only at rest and in transit, but also in use. The other options are not accurate descriptions of the key features and benefits of OCI Confidential Computing. Reference: [Confidential Computing]

questions.question_text: Which statement accurately describes the key features and benefits of OCI Confidential Computing?

choices.A: It optimizes network performance and reduces latency through advanced routing algorithms and caching mechanisms.
choices.B: It provides automatic scalability and load balancing capabilities, which allow seamless integration with other cloud providers.
choices.C: It encrypts and isolates in-use data and the applications processing that data, thereby preventing unauthorized access or modification.
choices.D: It enables users to securely store and retrieve data by using distributed file systems, ensuring high availability and fault tolerance.

discussion.content:
Hmmm... 
Option B is correct. But I am not sure, whether C is correct: 

states, that with the ObjectCollectionRule you can collect logs FROM Object Store. I did not see anything about storing them.

Whereas a Service Connector (Answer D) is used to " collect custom logs from OCI Streaming"

Cloud Agent Plugin (Option B):

The Oracle Cloud Agent can be installed on the on-premises instances to collect and forward logs to the OCI Logging service.
The Cloud Agent supports various plugins, and you can configure it to use the Logging service plugin to send logs to OCI.
ObjectCollectionRule (Option C):

ObjectCollectionRule is part of the OCI Logging service and allows you to define rules for collecting and storing logs.
You can create an ObjectCollectionRule to specifically target and collect logs at the Info level from the on-premises instances and store them in OCI Object Storage.
Options A (Grouping Function), D (Service Connectors), and E (Agent Configuration) are not directly related to achieving the specific requirement of archiving Info-level logging data to OCI Object Storage.

questions.question_text:
You are part of a team that manages a set of workload instances running in an on-premises environment. The Architect team is tasked with designing and configuring Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) Logging service to collect logs from these instances. There is a requirement to archive Info-level logging data of these instances into the OCI Object Storage.
Which TWO features of OCI can help you achieve this? (Choose two.)

choices.B: Deny public access to Oracle Cloud Infrastructure resources, such as databases and object storage buckets.
choices.A: Allow access to an unsecured compartment, which is moved from a standard compartment.
choices.D: Encrypt storage resources with a customer-managed key.
choices.C: Add or move a standard compartment to a highly secured security zone compartment.

questions.question_text: In which two ways can Oracle Security Zones assist with the cloud security shared responsibility model? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) offers best-in-class security technology and operational processes to secure its enterprise cloud services. Customers are responsible for securing their workloads and configuring their services and applications securely to meet their compliance obligations. Oracle Security Zones can assist with the cloud security shared responsibility model in the following ways:

Deny public access to Oracle Cloud Infrastructure resources, such as databases and object storage buckets
Enforce the policy that requires detached storage resources to reside in the same secure compartment as the compute instance
Encrypt storage resources, such as block volumes, object storage buckets, and databases, with a customer-managed key

questions.question_text:
A financial firm is designing an application architecture for its online trading platform that should have high availability and fault tolerance.
Their solutions architect configured the application to use an Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) Object Storage bucket located in the US West (us-phoenix-1) region to store large amounts of financial data. The stored financial data in the bucket should not be impacted even if there is an outage in one of the Availability Domains or a complete region.
What should the architect do to avoid any costly service disruption and ensure data durability?

choices.B: Create a replication policy to send data to a different bucket in another OCI region.
choices.D: Create a new Object Storage bucket in another region and configure lifecycle policy to move data every 5 days.
choices.A: Create a lifecycle policy to regularly send data from the Standard to Archive storage.
choices.C: Copy the Object Storage bucket to a block volume.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. Is correct

To ensure high availability, fault tolerance, and data durability in case of a complete regional outage, it's necessary to replicate the data to a different region.
Oracle Cloud Infrastructure allows you to configure replication policies between Object Storage buckets in different regions. This ensures that data is automatically copied to another region, protecting it from regional failures.
Other options do not guarantee durability or availability in the event of a regional failure. For example, moving data to archive storage or block volumes does not provide cross-region replication, and lifecycle policies alone are insufficient for protection against outages.
B. Create a replication policy to send data to a different bucket in another OCI region.

Selected Answer: B
B is most appropiate choice of the question.

choices.A: Configure two FastConnect virtual circuits to the us-ashburn-1 region and terminate them in diverse hardware on-premises.
choices.C: Configure a Site-to-Site VPN from a single on-premises CPE.
choices.D: Configure one FastConnect virtual circuit to the us-ashburn-1 region and a Site-to-Site VPN to the us-ashburn-1 region.
choices.B: Configure one FastConnect virtual circuit to the us-ashburn-1 region and the second FastConnect virtual circuit to the us-phoenix-1 region.

questions.question_text:
As a network architect you have been tasked with creating a fully redundant connection from your on-premises data center to your Virtual Cloud Network (VCN) in the us-ashburn-1 region.
Which TWO options will accomplish this requirement? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
I go with AD

B - connection to phoenix doesn't have anything to do with the connection in ashburn
C - not redundant

Selected Answer: AD
AD for me
A and D. Replication through either 2 fast connect links or fast connect + site 2 site vpn

Selected Answer: AD
Agree with the user "fklm".

Selected Answer: AB
Redundancy at network level and geographic level

Correct. Since, Option B (Configuring a FastConnect virtual circuit to the us-phoenix-1 region) is not necessary for creating redundancy to the us-ashburn-1 region. Option C (Configuring a Site-to-Site VPN from a single on-premises CPE) does not provide redundancy by itself, as it relies on a single connection. Therefore, options A and D are the most suitable for achieving a fully redundant connection to the us-ashburn-1 region.
